items.content_html:
Sharing some info about Apple Watch Ultra 3‚Äôs battery life: it dropped by 50% over 34 hours (from Wed 5:36 pm to Fri 3:36 am), by 40% in 24 hours with AOD on (from Tue 4:03 am to Wed 4:27 am) and by 30% in 24 hours with AOD off (from Wed 5:36 pm to Thu 5:55 pm). It‚Äôs quite the powerhouse!

By the way, it took about an hour and 14 minutes to charge from 50% to full on a 5-watt charger, and 50% to 80% was significantly faster.
items.content_text: Sharing some info about Apple Watch Ultra 3‚Äôs battery life: it dropped by 50% over 34 hours (from Wed 5:36 pm to Fri 3:36 am), by 40% in 24 hours with AOD on (from Tue 4:03 am to Wed 4:27 am) and by 30% in 24 hours with AOD off (from Wed 5:36 pm to Thu 5:55 pm). It‚Äôs quite the powerhouse! By the way, it took about an hour and 14 minutes to charge from 50% to full on a 5-watt charger, and 50% to 80% was significantly faster.

items.title: How Would You Prove That All Naturally Occurring Elements Have Been Discovered?
items.content_html:
You can‚Äôt prove it in the mathematical sense ‚Äî because the claim ‚Äúthere are no undiscovered naturally occurring elements‚Äù is a universal negative. In science, you can only make it extremely unlikely by combining (1) theory about what could exist and persist in nature, and (2) very broad, very sensitive searches that would almost certainly have detected it if it were there.

Here‚Äôs what the best ‚Äúproof-like‚Äù argument looks like.

1) Be clear what ‚Äúnaturally occurring‚Äù means

On Earth, the standard statement is: 94 elements occur naturally (at least in trace amounts), and the rest have only been made in labs. Separately, the number of officially recognized elements is currently 118. (Definitions matter because some elements exist only as tiny traces produced by decay chains or rare natural nuclear reactions, yet they still count as ‚Äúnaturally occurring.‚Äù)

2) Physics makes ‚Äúnew natural elements on Earth‚Äù very unlikely

To ‚Äústill exist on Earth,‚Äù an element needs either:

  • Primordial survival: an isotope with a half-life comparable to Earth‚Äôs age, or
  • Ongoing natural production: it‚Äôs continuously made (by decay chains, spontaneous fission, neutron capture, etc.) fast enough that small amounts are always present.

For very heavy elements, nuclear stability drops sharply, and the known superheavy isotopes tend to have extremely short half-lives; the long-hypothesized ‚Äúisland of stability‚Äù (where some superheavy isotopes might live longer) is still predicted and not observed in a way that would imply ‚Äúnatural stockpiles on Earth.‚Äù And even if longer-lived superheavy isotopes exist, models and discussion in the literature note big obstacles to them being made in nature and persisting in measurable quantities on Earth. So the theory side doesn‚Äôt give you a watertight ‚Äúimpossible,‚Äù but it does say: if something undiscovered exists naturally on Earth, it‚Äôs likely to be extremely rare and/or extremely short-lived.

3) Empirical ‚Äúnear-proof‚Äù: show we would have seen it

This is the part that makes the claim practically convincing.

To defend ‚Äúwe‚Äôve found them all,‚Äù you‚Äôd point to the fact that we‚Äôve thoroughly examined:

  • Earth materials (minerals, ores, sediments, ocean/atmosphere samples) with high-sensitivity mass spectrometry and radiochemical methods,
  • meteorites (which preserve early-solar-system material),
  • natural decay chains and their daughter products,
  • astronomical spectroscopy (elements leave distinctive spectral fingerprints in stars and explosions).

If a genuinely new naturally occurring element were present above those detection thresholds, it would likely show up as:

  • an unknown set of isotope masses and decay signatures, or
  • a new spectral line pattern consistent across observations.

What you can ‚Äúprove‚Äù here is conditional:

Given our detection limits and coverage, any undiscovered naturally occurring element must be below X abundance (or have half-life below Y, or be produced only in fleeting events), otherwise it would have been detected.

That‚Äôs as strong as science can get on this type of claim.

4) Why the statement can never be absolute

Even with all that, you can‚Äôt rule out edge cases like:

  • a superheavy isotope produced rarely in cosmic events and appearing on Earth at vanishingly small levels,
  • an element that exists only in extreme environments (e.g., briefly in stellar explosions) and not as a persistent ‚Äúthing you can bottle,‚Äù
  • something present below current detection limits.

So the honest conclusion is:

You can‚Äôt prove we‚Äôve discovered all naturally occurring elements. But you can argue that if any remain undiscovered on Earth, they‚Äôre likely so rare/short-lived that they don‚Äôt meaningfully change chemistry or the practical periodic table ‚Äî and you can quantify how rare they‚Äôd have to be based on modern searches.

items.content_html: Apple Music Replay ‘25 is out. Men I Trust remains my favourite artist/band this year. I‚Äôm the Problem kind of took me by surprise because I‚Äôve hardly been pegged as a country music fan since I was born. This album is just right. 53,794 minutes is approximately 900 hours, which appears to be a lot.
items.content_text: Apple Music Replay '25 is out. [Men I Trust](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Men_I_Trust) remains my favourite artist/band this year. [I‚Äôm the Problem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I'm_the_Problem_(Morgan_Wallen_album)) kind of took me by surprise because I‚Äôve hardly been pegged as a country music fan since I was born. This album is just right. 53,794 minutes is approximately 900 hours, which appears to be a lot.

items.content_html:
Vancouver Sleep Clinic hails from Brisbane, Australia.

of Montreal is from Georgia, USA.

Secretly Canadian is based in Indiana, USA.

CANADA is headquartered in Barcelona, Spain.

Yukon Gold is indeed Canadian, but it‚Äôs not from Yukon but Guelph, Ontario.

Bottom line: Canada needs rules of nomenclature.
items.content_text:
[Vancouver Sleep Clinic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vancouver_Sleep_Clinic) hails from Brisbane, Australia.   

[of Montreal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Of_Montreal) is from Georgia, USA.   

[Secretly Canadian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secretly_Canadian) is based in Indiana, USA.   

[CANADA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canada_(company)) is headquartered in Barcelona, Spain.   

[Yukon Gold](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yukon_Gold_potato) is indeed Canadian, but it‚Äôs not from Yukon but Guelph, Ontario.   

Bottom line: Canada needs rules of nomenclature.

items.title: Full Moon
items.content_html:
I was lucky to see scenery straight out of a Ghibli movie in real life.

What comes to mind when you see the full moon?

For me, it‚Äôs always this passage from The Sheltering Sky:

Because we don’t know when we will die
We get to think of life as an inexhaustible well
Yet everything happens only a certain number of times
And a very small number, really
How many more times will you remember a certain afternoon of your childhood
Some afternoon that is so deeply a part of your being that you can’t even conceive your life without it?
Perhaps four or five times more
Perhaps not even that
How many more times will you watch the full moon rise?
Perhaps twenty, and yet it all seems limitless
‚Äî Paul Bowles
items.content_text:
I was lucky to see scenery straight out of a Ghibli movie in real life. What comes to mind when you see the full moon? For me, it‚Äôs always this passage from _The Sheltering Sky_: > Because we don't know when we will die We get to think of life as an inexhaustible well Yet everything happens only a certain number of times And a very small number, really How many more times will you remember a certain afternoon of your childhood Some afternoon that is so deeply a part of your being that you can't even conceive your life without it? Perhaps four or five times more Perhaps not even that How many more times will you watch the full moon rise? Perhaps twenty, and yet it all seems limitless ‚Äî Paul Bowles
üéß fullmoon (immersion 2023)

items.title: A Little Thought on "Bad Habits"
items.content_html:
When a person cannot satisfy their deeper emotional needs, like love, security, belonging, or purpose, they often redirect that emptiness into various substitute desires / compensatory behaviours that afford immediate pleasures or comforts. These substitutes can become excessive, inappropriate, or addictive, thus often referred to as “bad habits.” Examples include:

  • Sexual desire (overly seeking sex)
  • Material desire (shopping, hoarding, etc.)
  • Food-related desires (overeating, binge eating, eating disorders, etc.)
  • Substance use (smoking, drinking alcohol)
  • Behavioural addictions (such as video games)

These compensations can feel soothing in the short term, but they don‚Äôt address the root cause. Over time, they can spiral into addictions or unhealthy patterns, which only widen the gap between what a person truly needs and what they‚Äôre chasing.

It‚Äôs clearly a vicious cycle: unmet needs ‚Üí temporary coping behaviours ‚Üí guilt/shame or further emptiness ‚Üí even stronger cravings. Breaking this cycle usually requires not just self-control, but also self-awareness and sometimes therapy to identify the underlying emotional void.

Addictions and compulsive behaviours aren‚Äôt just “bad habits.” They‚Äôre often signals that something deeper in us is being ignored. If we learn to listen to those signals instead of numbing them, we can actually grow in healthier ways.

- Sexual desire (overly seeking sex)
- Material desire (shopping, hoarding, etc.)
- Food-related desires (overeating, binge eating, eating disorders, etc.)
- Substance use (smoking, drinking alcohol)
- Behavioural addictions (such as video games)  

These compensations can feel soothing in the short term, but they don‚Äôt address the root cause. Over time, they can spiral into addictions or unhealthy patterns, which only widen the gap between what a person truly needs and what they‚Äôre chasing.  

It‚Äôs clearly a vicious cycle: unmet needs ‚Üí temporary coping behaviours ‚Üí guilt/shame or further emptiness ‚Üí even stronger cravings. Breaking this cycle usually requires not just self-control, but also self-awareness and sometimes therapy to identify the underlying emotional void.

Addictions and compulsive behaviours aren‚Äôt just "bad habits." They‚Äôre often signals that something deeper in us is being ignored. If we learn to listen to those signals instead of numbing them, we can actually grow in healthier ways.

items.content_html:
I‚Äôve been a proud Endel Premium user since the fall of 2020. As of now, I have spent 1709 days with the app and averaged about 4 hours of use every night.

I honestly can‚Äôt sleep properly without my CPAP or Endel‚Äôs Sleep soundscape. This wonderful app has been part of my sleep routine for a few weeks shy of five years.

items.content_html: It looked like the links and icons on my site were shifting upward in dark mode on hover, but nothing changed in the CSS. Light mode had no issues. After some digging, I realized it was an optical illusion caused by the colour contrast. Changing the hover colour fixed it.

items.title: Which will die first, Vega, Altair, or the Sun?
items.content_html:
Among the three stars ‚Äî Vega, Altair, and the Sun ‚Äî Vega will die first, followed by Altair, and then our Sun, which will be the last to reach the end of its life.

The primary reason for this sequence lies in their masses and lifespans, which are inversely related: the more massive a star, the faster it burns through its nuclear fuel and the shorter its lifespan.

Stellar Mass and Lifespan: The Trade-Off

To understand this better, let‚Äôs compare their masses and expected main-sequence lifespans:

  • Vega, the brightest star in the constellation Lyra, is more than twice as massive as the Sun. It is a relatively young star, around 450 million years old, and is already about halfway through its main-sequence life. At this pace, it‚Äôs expected to exhaust its core hydrogen in less than 500 million years from now.
  • Altair, the brightest star in Aquila, is slightly less massive than Vega and rotates very rapidly. Its mass gives it a longer lifespan than Vega‚Äîabout 1 to 2 billion years in total.
  • The Sun, our middle-aged yellow dwarf, has an estimated total lifespan of about 10 billion years. Currently, it is about 4.6 billion years old, with roughly 5 billion years remaining before it leaves the main sequence.

Why Bigger Stars Die Sooner

Massive stars have stronger gravitational pressure at their cores, which leads to higher temperatures and faster nuclear fusion. Although they have more fuel to burn, they burn it much more rapidly, dramatically shortening their lifespans.

In contrast, stars like the Sun burn fuel more slowly and steadily, giving them far longer to shine.

Conclusion

Vega will die first, likely within a few hundred million years. Altair will follow, and the Sun will live the longest of the three. Their fates serve as a reminder of the delicate balance between mass, energy, and time in stellar evolution.

It is a relatively young star, around 450 million years old, and is already about halfway through its main-sequence life. At this pace, it‚Äôs expected to exhaust its core hydrogen in less than 500 million years from now. - Altair, the brightest star in Aquila, is slightly less massive than Vega and rotates very rapidly. Its mass gives it a longer lifespan than Vega‚Äîabout 1 to 2 billion years in total. - The Sun, our middle-aged yellow dwarf, has an estimated total lifespan of about 10 billion years. Currently, it is about 4.6 billion years old, with roughly 5 billion years remaining before it leaves the main sequence. ### Why Bigger Stars Die Sooner Massive stars have stronger gravitational pressure at their cores, which leads to higher temperatures and faster nuclear fusion. Although they have more fuel to burn, they burn it much more rapidly, dramatically shortening their lifespans. In contrast, stars like the Sun burn fuel more slowly and steadily, giving them far longer to shine. ### Conclusion Vega will die first, likely within a few hundred million years. Altair will follow, and the Sun will live the longest of the three. Their fates serve as a reminder of the delicate balance between mass, energy, and time in stellar evolution.
by ChatGPT GPT-4o

I‚Äôve switched back to the 24-hour notation on my main site, blog, and every other site I control. I‚Äôve always been a fan of the 24-hour system, and the Canadian government encourages its use too. So‚Ä¶ I figure doing a bit of mental math (like remembering that 00 is 12 a.m., 12 is 12 p.m., and subtracting 12 if the hour‚Äôs over 12) isn‚Äôt that hard, eh?

items.title: Remnant
items.content_html:
The earthquake struck when I was six.
I survived.
Most of my classmates didn‚Äôt.

Now I‚Äôm in college, in another city.
Whenever I return home, I pass their parents on the street.
They stop me,
their eyes scanning me ‚Äî
as if searching for what might have been.
Then, with a gentle, aching smile, they say,
‚ÄúYou‚Äôve grown so much.‚Äù
items.content_text:
The earthquake struck when I was six.  
I survived.  
Most of my classmates didn‚Äôt.  

Now I‚Äôm in college, in another city.  
Whenever I return home, I pass their parents on the street.  
They stop me,  
their eyes scanning me ‚Äî  
as if searching for what might have been.  
Then, with a gentle, aching smile, they say,

items.title: My 12 Lessons of Life
items.content_html:
Lesson 01: I am not the centre of everyone‚Äôs attention
Lesson 02: Learn to embrace farewells
Lesson 03: No one will care about me forever
Lesson 04: Master my emotions
Lesson 05: Love myself before I love anyone else
Lesson 06: Health is my greatest wealth
Lesson 07: Accept every regret with grace
Lesson 08: Save my anger for what truly matters
Lesson 09: Embrace my own imperfections
Lesson 10: Learn to find joy in solitude
Lesson 11: Brave souls savour the world
Lesson 12: Always stay true to myself

Trapped in the claws of the bear
And I wonder
Will all things be empty again?

Cold till it burns
You’ll be blowing away the frostbites
When we’ll return

items.title: Snacks
items.content_html: Granny hands me a bag of snacks, edges soft, the crunch long gone. I look at Mom and ask, ‚ÄúDid they expire?‚Äù She smiles, half-lost in thought, ‚ÄúNo, love ‚Äî we just came home too late.‚Äù
items.content_text:
Granny hands me a bag of snacks,
edges soft, the crunch long gone.
I look at Mom and ask,
‚ÄúDid they expire?‚Äù
She smiles, half-lost in thought,
‚ÄúNo, love ‚Äî we just came home too late.‚Äù

items.content_html: I‚Äôm not impressed by how PDF Expert provides their lifetime subscription. For a one-time payment of CA$199.99 (or US$97.99 on StackSocial), customers have no access to their future big updates and new features, including the AI assistant. Also, it‚Äôs macOS only; the mobile apps are not included.
items.content_text: I‚Äôm not impressed by how [PDF Expert provides their lifetime subscription](https://pdfexpert.com/pricing). For a one-time payment of CA$199.99 (or [US$97.99 on StackSocial](https://www.stacksocial.com/sales/pdf-expert-premium-plan-lifetime)), customers have no access to their future big updates and new features, including the AI assistant. Also, it‚Äôs macOS only; the mobile apps are not included.

items.content_html:
Oops‚Ä¶ Just found out that Silicon Valley‚Äôs trendy social media app Airchat is already toast. Its official website has shut down. That was fast!

While Elie Steinbock believed that Airchat would change social media forever, Elaine Moore was right on the money ‚Äî Airchat‚Äôs viral success will not last.
items.content_text:
Oops‚Ä¶ Just found out that Silicon Valley‚Äôs trendy social media app [Airchat](https://apps.apple.com/ca/app/airchat-just-talk/id1469462351) is already toast. Its [official website](https://air.chat) has shut down. That was fast!

While [Elie Steinbock](https://www.indiehackers.com/elie222) believed that [Airchat would change social media forever](https://www.indiehackers.com/post/why-airchat-will-change-social-media-forever-2caaa3336f), Elaine Moore was right on the money ‚Äî [Airchat‚Äôs viral success will not last](https://www.ft.com/content/177d2cb8-777b-48e4-8abf-2f6057aa9c4b).

items.content_html:
Back in 1980, KFC had around 6,000 locations across 48 countries, pulling in $2 billion a year ($2 billion in 1980 is roughly $7.66 billion in today‚Äôs dollars).

Fast forward to 2023, and the brand had grown to nearly 30,000 outlets in 145 countries, with annual sales reaching $2.83 billion.
items.content_text:
Back in **1980**, KFC had around **6,000** locations across **48** countries, pulling in **$2 billion** a year ($2 billion in 1980 is roughly $7.66 billion in today‚Äôs dollars).

Fast forward to **2023**, and the brand had grown to nearly **30,000** outlets in **145** countries, with annual sales reaching **$2.83 billion**.

items.content_html:
JavaScript short date-time format:

  • United States: Tue, 02/18/2025, 1:58 AM EST
  • Canada: Tue, 2025-02-18, 1:58 a.m. EST

Without a doubt, the Canadian short date looks cleaner and more visually appealing, and the ‚Äúa.m.‚Äù (or ‚Äúp.m.‚Äù) style has a classic touch. However, it‚Äôs four characters long. Also, in the long date-time format, the word ‚Äúat‚Äù appears between the date and time, whereas in the short version, it‚Äôs simply replaced by a comma. I dislike seeing more than one comma in a timestamp, so on this site, what you actually see is a hybrid version: Tue, 2025-02-18 @ 1:58 AM EST.
items.content_text:
JavaScript short date-time format:
- United States: Tue, 02/18/2025, 1:58 AM EST
- Canada: Tue, 2025-02-18, 1:58 a.m. EST

Without a doubt, the Canadian short date looks cleaner and more visually appealing, and the ‚Äúa.m.‚Äù (or ‚Äúp.m.‚Äù) style has a classic touch. However, it‚Äôs four characters long. Also, in the long date-time format, the word ‚Äúat‚Äù appears between the date and time, whereas in the short version, it‚Äôs simply replaced by a comma. I dislike seeing more than one comma in a timestamp, so on this site, what you actually see is a hybrid version: **Tue, 2025-02-18 @ 1:58 AM EST**.

items.content_html:
*Driving with Google Maps on Apple CarPlay*

Me: Hey Siri, cancel this trip.  Siri: There‚Äôs nothing called ‚ÄúTrip‚Äù on your calendar.  Me: Cancel this current trip on Google Maps.  Siri: You‚Äôre not navigating in Apple Maps at the moment.  Me: Exit this trip. Siri: Sorry, I don‚Äôt understand.
items.content_text:
\*Driving with Google Maps on Apple CarPlay\* Me: Hey Siri, cancel this trip.
 Siri: There‚Äôs nothing called ‚ÄúTrip‚Äù on your calendar. 
Me: Cancel this current trip on Google Maps. 
Siri: You‚Äôre not navigating in Apple Maps at the moment. 
Me: Exit this trip.
Siri: Sorry, I don‚Äôt understand.

items.content_html: Places like Value Village always leave me with mixed emotions. As soon as I walk in, I feel a rush of excitement. There‚Äôs an eclectic assortment of items, many of them surprisingly decent and offered at affordable prices. But in the end, I always feel a bit sentimental. These items were likely cherished by their original owners at one time, only to end up being sold for next to nothing. It‚Äôs bittersweet ‚Äî and in a way, it feels like a reflection of human relationships.

These items were likely cherished by their original owners at one time, only to end up being sold for next to nothing. It‚Äôs bittersweet ‚Äî and in a way, it feels like a reflection of human relationships.

items.title: If I named this post ¬´Unconditional Love¬ª it would come off as a clich√© but honestly that‚Äôs what it‚Äôs all about
items.content_html: <!-- raw HTML omitted -->
items.content_text:
During the chaos of my parents‚Äô divorce (when I was around 11), my uncles on my mother‚Äôs side (or maybe my grandmother‚ÄîI can‚Äôt quite remember, but it doesn‚Äôt really matter since they shared the same values) offered to take me to a theme park out of town. But shortly after, they had a change of heart. They wanted to see who I would end up living with. Basically, if I had chosen to stay with my dad, whom they saw as their sworn enemy, they wouldn‚Äôt have bothered with me or the trip. I have to admit, for most of my adult life, I didn‚Äôt think anything was wrong with that‚Äîit‚Äôs kind of like how economics works: your employer is likely to withdraw benefits when they know you‚Äôre intent on leaving for another employer, seeing it as a way to avoid needless losses.

However, when I casually mentioned this to my landlord (yes, I‚Äôve had many heart-to-hearts with this older lady), she was surprised, even a bit confused. She was like, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what they were thinking, but if you were my grandchild and I knew you were leaving us to live with your dad, I‚Äôd want to take you anywhere you wanted and give you the best I could‚Äîbecause I wouldn‚Äôt know when I‚Äôd see you again.‚Äù

My eyes welled up. I was genuinely shocked to hear such a different perspective. Some people strictly prioritize benefits over kindness, while others don‚Äôt really care about gains and losses. It really got me thinking a lot about family values and what unconditional love truly meant. At one point, I even felt like I didn‚Äôt really know what love was.

I couldn‚Äôt choose the family I was born into, but I can choose to carry that conversation with me forever.

items.content_html: I wonder if there is a way for these music streaming platforms to prevent what I call “namespace pollution.” This term refers to different artists sharing the same name and being grouped together on a single artist page, especially when they are mononymous or have very common names. It‚Äôs really frustrating because, despite having the same name, these artists often create music in completely different genres and languages!
items.content_text: I wonder if there is a way for these music streaming platforms to prevent what I call "**namespace pollution**." This term refers to different artists sharing the same name and being grouped together on a single artist page, especially when they are mononymous or have very common names. It‚Äôs really frustrating because, despite having the same name, these artists often create music in completely different genres and languages!
